awd_titl_txt: 3D Experimental and Computational Studies  of Crystallographic Effects on Creep and Fracture in  Salt Rock
awd_abstract_narration:
Rock salt, a sedimentary rock classified as an evaporate, forms as a result of evaporation of inland seas or any enclosed body of water, and can be found in nature as bedded or domal formations.  Salt domes often trap oil, gas, and other minerals around their edges.  Salt caverns are large cavities or chambers that form inside underground salt deposits either naturally by the effect of geological processes or are man-made.  They have been used as storage for different types of hydrocarbons since early 1970s including the US strategic petroleum reserve.  Salt caverns may potentially serve as a long-term and safe repository for carbon dioxide, nuclear waste, and the waste of oil drilling operations.   Drilling through rock salt poses many challenges, including long-term wellbore stability/integrity, casing collapse due to lateral pressure, and drilling fluid-salt interaction.  The accuracy with which the fracture behavior of any material can be simulated, including geological materials like rock, hinges upon the fidelity of both the engineering model and the geometrical representation of the cracked body.  The anisotropic response of rock salt during creep deformations is stress and temperature dependent, and the accumulated creep strain influences fracture nucleation.  This behavior creates many challenges when rock salt formations interact with sources of thermal and stress changes.  An improved and quantitative understanding of when, where, and how cracks evolve within 3D polycrystalline rocks has many important technological implications with potential benefits for modeling drilling, geothermal-energy extraction, carbon sequestration, machine-rock interaction, and explosive penetration.  This project (i) impacts the research community and promotes technology transfer; (ii) involves minority/female undergraduate students in conducting cutting-edge engineering research; and (iii) engages the next generation of scientists through the involvement of high school students in research, sparking their interest in the field of civil engineering and helping contribute to the quality of the next generation of civil engineering educators and professionals.

A key limitation of existing phenomenological creep models is that rock salt's anisotropic response is not represented at the microstructural level.  While crystal plasticity models for capturing anisotropy in rock salt do exist, they employ empirical flow rate equations which are valid for a narrow range of temperature and strain rate.  Presently, there is an apparent lack of crystal-orientation-sensitive models in the literature for creep and fracture in 3D rock specimens coupled with direct measurements of 3D crystal structure. Thus, this research will combine nondestructive 3D x-ray diffraction (3DXRD), 3D synchrotron micro-computed tomography (SMT) in-situ experimental measurements, and 3D crystal-plasticity modeling to enhance current understanding of creep and crack formation and growth mechanisms in polycrystalline rock is unprecedented in many regards.  The ability to experimentally measure lattice strains within the microstructure of rock has recently been demonstrated by the PI.  These enhanced experimental techniques provide us with a richer dataset for calibrating the microstructural constitutive model accounting for anisotropy.  By employing dislocation mechanism-based crystal plasticity models, we plan to elucidate the governing mechanisms operating in the halite crystals that yield the observed creep and fracture response.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Rock salt, a sedimentary rock classified as an evaporate, forms as a result of evaporation of inland seas or any enclosed bodies of water and can be found in nature as bedded or domal formation. Salt caverns are huge cavities or chambers that form inside underground salt deposits either naturally by the effect of geological processes or are man-made. They have been used as storage for different types of hydrocarbons since the early 1970s including the US strategic petroleum reserve. Salt caverns can potentially serve as a long-term and safe repository for carbon dioxide, nuclear waste, and the waste of oil drilling operations.

As the demand for energy increases and the anticipated rise of oil prices in the near future, the oil industry is tapping into sources in deep water and unconventional reservoirs. Rock salt’s very low porosity and impermeability to hydrocarbons allow it to trap oil and gas in nature. Drilling through rock salt to reach oil reservoirs poses many challenges, including long-term wellbore stability/integrity, casing collapse due to lateral pressure, and drilling fluid-salt interaction (Fredrich et al., 2003). The accuracy with which the fracture behavior of any material can be simulated, including geological materials like rock, hinges upon the fidelity of both the constitutive model and the geometrical representation of the cracked body. The 3D micro-structurally small cracks in rocks are still not well understood and thus offer open areas of research (both experimentally and computationally).

The objective of the proposed research was to use 3D x-ray diffraction (3DXRD) and Synchrotron micro-computed tomography (SMT) complemented by 3D crystal plasticity finite element (FE) modeling to answer fundamental questions about anisotropy, creep behavior, crack onset and fracture behavior of halite (sodium chloride), a mineral commonly known as rock salt or simply salt. Creep and unconfined compression experiments were conducted on natural single crystal and synthetic specimens of rock salt and different crystal orientation and temperature.

Laboratory One-dimensional (1-D) compression experiments simulates the transition of small halite grains into rock salt formations in nature and by changing the ambient condition during the 1-D compression small-scale representations of various rock salt formations can be created. The 1-D compression and consolidation of halite grains into polycrystalline rock salt was studied. This study not only furthered the understanding of rock salt’s behavior in 1-D compression but also established critical porosity values during the study where the behavior of the material changes drastically. Moreover, the effects of the 1-D compression ambient condition on properties of polycrystalline rock salt was investigated which results in better understanding the behavior of rock salt formations being considered for storage. A new high-pressure thermal triaxial cell was designed that is significantly cost-effective and whose features make it a suitable and safe apparatus for testing rock salt or other rocks. The effects of elevated temperature on the properties of rock salt under loads from various directions with respect to its crystal orientation was investigated which can be implemented in the designing storages within rock salt formations and improving their structural safety. The evolution of texture, lattice stresses, and crack networks within rock salt under compression loads was studied. This part of the study not only provides vital information that can be used in numerical models and other fundamental research on rock salt but also provides insights into critical stress values that surpassing which can lead into the evolution of crack networks within rock salt and can compromise the impermeability of the material. Using the test data, a 3D dislocation-density-based crystal plasticity model for rock salt was developed that accurately predicts the stress-strain behavior of artificial rock salt when loaded against different crystal orientations, a wide range of quasi-static to dynamic strain rates, and temperatures up to 100 o C. The same model form was utilized with a recalibration of the parameters to match the experimental response of natural rock salt. Subsequently, the proposed model captured the ratcheting phenomenon of natural rock salt during cyclic unconfined 1D compression tests by relying upon the accumulating viscoplastic flow that is tracked in the model on the activated slip systems.

The research combined novel nondestructive 3D x-ray diffraction (3DXRD) and 3D synchrotron micro-computed tomography (SMT) techniques in a world-class facility (APS) to probe specimens and conduct in-situ experimental measurements with mechanism-based crystal-plasticity modeling to elucidate the governing mechanisms operating in halite crystals that yield the observed creep and fracture response. These techniques enable direct measurement of lattice strain within the 3D rock specimens that provide a richer dataset for calibrating the crystal plasticity model accounting for crystal orientation and anisotropic strength. Additionally, the effect of crystal lattice orientation on the propagation of fracture networks in halite was observed by SMT and modeled by cohesive zone (CZ) finite element models.

 


Last Modified: 12/25/2021
Modified by: Khalid Alshibli
